posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How do cis people benefit for being actively trans-positive? How does the trans-positive movement reward its supporters?

It seems to me that it doesn't. It seems like the movement expects total conformity without a single positive incentive. I will admit that the movement punishes apostates with the fury of a sysadmin scorned. They can fuck up your web shit.

But contrast this with what the trans-exclusionary movement gives normal supporters: book deals, speaking engagements, and for the layperson some communities like mumsnet. The trans-positive movement, for all its rage and all its discord servers, hasn't even taken down mumsnet. Kwii farms is back online. My point being, the movement isn't really expanding its base OR hurting its enemies.

The real threat to the trans-positive movement is complacency. Complacency gets cis people everything they want. It is exactly as rewarding as trans-positivity but bears no risk of being a hated apostate. A complacent person can always just plead ignorance if you say something like "non binary doesn't make sense." And most importantly, a complacent person gets to opt out of all of the demands that the trans-positive movement makes for attention, influence, power. It's like the perfect solution for a cis person's needs.

Now you might say, "the trans movement doesn't need the support of cis people. We are a radical underground gender rebellion brewing up bathtub hormones. Be gay and do crimes." And to that I say, "good luck." Because there's at least 25% of cis people who would be happy to put you in conversion therapy, and if you're not using state power then they are. And if your plan is to resort to being a terrorist underground fighting a state power... What does this movement have to offer anyone anymore? What does this movement have to offer a scared queer 20-something in a dead town in Ohio who is thinking about the worst alternatives to transitioning?

What's the materially positive part of this anymore?

nope, not at all.
most antidepressants are ssri (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) or snri and those are commonly seen to cause that
welbutrin, on the other hand is a ndri (norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor) and is actually (i think) the only one like that out there like that. it works on completely different chemicals.

but importantly:talk to your doctor, ssris work for a lot of people so don't discont them, but be aware of the side effects. also, for anyone who havent had ssris work for them, try talking to your doctor about welbutrin because it could work much better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
New Paycheck Edition
previous: >>29004378

Goal of the thread: Open your window for 10-20 minutes, maybe have a walk if the weather allows.
Daily goals can be repeated. Remember to keep score, it can only go up!

>What is this thread for?
Getting better is hard, and sucks. A lot. It does not get easier doing it alone.
Share resources and experiences with combating depression, anxiety, personal issues, achieving or maintaining a healthy weight, etc.
>Why is this thread /lgbt/?
Struggles with mental and physical health are an indisputable part of /lgbt/ life, be it from dysphoria, social pressure, heartbreak, or just unfortunate lifestyle choices.
>Notes to consider:
Please be civil. Shame is your greatest enemy in fighting urges of self abuse (be it sh, drugs, or just self deprecation). Relapsing into bad and unhealthy habits is to be expected, the goal is to increase the average amount of time it takes between relapses. Any improvement is a victory no matter how small. Your worth and right to get better are non-negotiable. And most importantly:
WE ARE NOT THERAPISTS, WE DON'T REPLACE MEDICATION
>Note on advice
Generic advice won't necessarily help you in particular, but for those it does it is an essential foundation to build future progress on, not a miracle cure. Do not underestimate the effects subtle changes to your lifestyle can have. Try first, keep us posted on your progress, build from there.

We are *always* short on self help resources, so if anything was useful to you, let us know!
Since the OP is getting too long I moved all resources into their own post, see below!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
resources:
Exercise, diet, weight loss/gain: >>>/fit/17018018 (sticky)
Assorted self help resources (anxiety, depression, sleep issues, ED, and more) https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself
NIMH brochures on mental health topics (Depression, BPD, ADHD, etc): https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications
ED: https://www.eatingdisorderhope.com/treatment-for-eating-disorders

General advice from Anons: https://0x0.st/o5Og.txt

Get started with weight loss (courtesy of /fit/fat/):
>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with LoseIt, Cronometer or Waistline (Open Source)

A few short overview videos (need review by other anons):
Common Sources of Misery: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LO1mTELoj6o
Loneliness and its Health Effects: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n3Xv_g3g-mA
Making Friends: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9hJ_Rux9y0
Impact of Gratitude Exercises: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WPPPFqsECz0
Habituation 101: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=75d_29QWELk
A "game" on anxiety (and the author's experience fighting it):
https://ncase.me/anxiety/ and https://ncase.me/mental-health/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Apart from the GOTT, here are a few things you can do _today_ to make your life a little better. Keep a diary and write down every success. Some you may do as often as you please, but write down each one individually! You deserve it! Do not feel pressured to do all, but feel free to select one or two!
Today I included all goals we had in any thread so far, for more choice <3

- eat a meal
- drink a glass of water
- try to exercise for 5 min (walk outdoors, walking stairs, whatever you wish)
- if you have a bad habit, try making it more inconvenient (putting things in hard to reach places for example)
- prepare 1 load of laundry
- do 1 load of laundry
- read one page of a book or manga you have been putting off

You can tell her that you reciprocated her feelings and do not know what to do with the current situation, that you value her a great deal and want to make things work one way or another. I haven't gotten out of bed in months (not literally, I get up to get food once a day) my room is so messy, there's so much stuff on the floor it's hard to walk, I can't remember the last time I took a shower.
I think this time I have enough energy to fight back but I keep saying "I will do it tomorrow" and then forgetting about it, there's so much I want to do, so many wasted opportunities, I have enough canned food and savings to "stay alive" for many months but I wanna get a job, I wanna gain skills, so many ways my life could improve, if only I tried.
I keep trying to avoid bothering anyone and thinking I can get out of this all by myself but this strategy hasn't worked out, plus I have ADHD and I keep getting distracted by everything, I know I should do all of the things anon said here >>29011793 but I keep getting distracted by my thoughts, at the end of the day I remember all the things I should have done, it's infuriating.

Talking to others can help my memory, do you think I could post here every day? Only if my posts don't bother you too much, it would add pressure so I'll feel encouraged to get out the bed, I'm so ashamed of how I'm living but I must face this shame in order to get better.

So I will start by trying getting out of this bed for the rest of the day, I'll get something to eat, it's 3 PM and I haven't gotten breakfast, I'll turn off my phone because I could be posting from my PC, that way at least I'll be sitting down instead of laying on my bed.
Thank you for these threads OP, I appreciate them, it's giving energy and maybe I'll get better this time.

There are a few useful pointers I can give right off the bat, with maybe some of the above resources being useful. If you wish to make personal progress on skills and such, habituation is the key. Essentially, the worst thing to do at all times is to wait for motivation or inspiration to strike. it usually does not. It is far easier to have some parts of your schedule fixed and work on something because you always work on that particular something around that time.

posts.name: glass halo
posts.com:
>>29047595
>really want to make games, and become good at art/3dmodeling but, am afraid to move towards it I think because I'm going to suck at it for a long time, and I dunno how to keep motivated without feeling like I'm making any progress.
it seems like you're experiencing a classic conflict between immediate satisfaction and the more costly, slow, stressful, but ultimately more satisfying work required for improving your skills and accomplishing your goals.

There are a lot of strategies for dealing with this like:
>Do work that you can finish. the goals that you set, and the work that set out to do should be as bite sized as possible while still being something you can learn from. This way you don't swallow more than you can chew, and you can see your progress over time.
>Work at something whenever you realize you're avoiding it. Avoiding the stress of your goals doesn't actually make you any less stressed. The more time you spend avoiding something, the more stressful it becomes to actually start. So you should do your best to train yourself to just nip that stress in the bud. >Ideally, your breaks should never feel like something you're using to avoid your problems or work, instead they should give you time to passively reflect on what you've done, what you're having trouble with, and to see it with fresh eyes.
>There will be times where you're not able to stop avoiding something, there will be times where your habits and your work falls apart, i see this as sort of like a sore muscle in your brain that just cant lift anymore. given enough time, you'll gain enough control again to keep going again, and so you shouldnt be too hard on yourself about it.

>>29049236
It should be tied to a particular time and/or place, action. Basically you wanna achieve an almost Pavlovian response: some context that your brain eventually associates with the action you wanna habituate, a time of day is perfect for that.
One of my most reliable habits for a great deal of my life was taking a walk every saturday noon, as an example.
You can adjust no problem, but it may be useful to have something consistent that you can condition yourself with, and that prevents you from postponing and procrastinating.

>But I think Its hard for me to interact with friends because I always want to seek attention and validation.
It is fine to seek it to some extent, you holding yourself back that much gets in the way. If you deprive yourself from validation entirely, you are depriving yourself of a valuable source of confidence that you lack.
>I am going to eventually act overbearing venting sad posting and not just hanging out in a fun way
everyone is different. Some people would be weighed down by those feelings with little ability to help, others would want to work through them with you. It is a matter of negotiation, but the unfortunate truth is that not everyone will be up for that in particular. Nonetheless, there are plenty of people who will let you communicate those needs. Leaning on people is natural and important, and growing as a person so others can lean on you too is one of the most wonderful experiences in life. But "I'm not feeling well because I've been overthinking something and could use someone to talk to" is not an unreasonable ask.

You absolutely need social contacts, and even though your past experiences clearly haunt you, and you will risk some rejection. You can watch the kurzgesagt vid on making friends as a little pep talk and refresher on how cultivating friendship, once you found people, often is a matter of time more than being some particular kind of person. But if you feel like you have no energy for it yet then I strongly recommend we start with something smaller. We need to force you to move around more. Leave the house daily, ideally. Good starting points are
>slowly cleaning up your room, increasing your overall comfort, letting fresh air in
>forming small habits that keep you moving
>set up a schedule and give you a backbone in your daily life to start rebuilding your energy.

j.1365-2265.1982.tb00728.x

>In the girls with gonadal dysgenesis (Group A), who had elevated levels of gonadotrophins, the institution of oestrogen substitution therapy instigated normal breast development, corresponding to mid-puberty (P3) after only 6 months of treatment, and with completion of development (Ps) in a considerable proportion after 3 years of treatment. In contrast the girls of Groups B and C, all of whom were deficient in gonadotrophins, showed only the development of breast buds (Pz) after 6 months of treatment and in none did breast development exceed stage P3 after 3 years of oestrogen substitution therapy. Similar results were noted by Burns et al. (1981) in girls with hypopituitarism due to craniopharyngioma.
These findings indicate that gonadotrophins are indispensable for the effectiveaction of oestrogen on breast development. It is of interest that a number ofcomprehensive reviews on the influence of hormones on the mammary gland fail to mention the possible effectsof gonadotrophins (Bassler, 1970; Porter, 1974; Ceriani, 1974; Topper & Freeman, 1980). Paulsen (1975)observed breast development in men with isolated LH deficiency(fertile eunuchs) but not in men with deficiencyof both LH and FSH. Thus it may be postulated that of the gonadotrophins FSH is the more important, apparently functioning as a permissive or priming factor for the action of oestrogen on the breast tissue, It would be of interest to test the cells of the mammary gland for the presence of receptors to gonadotrophins or FSH."

For example say your lil sister wants a full family dinner for her birthday. Then your parents come over and double down on treating you like shit and start guilting you for abandoning family and get back on their petty homophobia bullshit and start acting like you owe them something. Better to be proactively a bitch than reactively. So if you do allow your less fucked up siblings stay with you set some clear rules with them. Explain you have no intention of repeating the bullshit your parents do. That you are trying to be better. Because you DO think you have the potential to be better than them. But explain your boundaries to them, ask them to have their own and let you know of them, and then the difficult work of enforcing them can be done.

>>29065057
>0.1% of users experience side effects on fin

>Sexual adverse effects are the most common category of complications from 5ARI use and have been documented to be anywhere from 0.9 to 38 percent.

>Irwig et al assessed depressive symptoms and suicidal thoughts in former users of finasteride. Otherwise healthy former users of finasteride (n=61) with hair loss and persistent sexual side effects for ≥3 months after discontinuing finasteride were compared against a control group of men with male pattern hair loss, but no sexual dysfunction (n=29). Depressive symptoms were found to be significantly higher in the finasteride group compared to the controls. Moderate or severe depressive symptoms were present in 64 percent of the finasteride group and zero percent of the controls. Suicidal thoughts were present in 44 percent of the former finasteride users and in three percent of the controls (p<0.0001). Confounding this study was the fact the finasteride user group also had sexual dysfunction and the control group did not.

64% of people who experienced sexual side effects from finasteride also experienced depression, and 44% were suicidal, with negligible numbers for controls of people with hair loss but no finasteride. Up to 38% have experienced sexual side effects.

Now, am I knowingly and unscientifically misrepresenting all of the connections between these numbers by intermixing information? Yes. But, but at the same time, due to the known mechanism of action, the known effects of DHT, anecdotal reports, and some studies showing extremely high adverse effect rates, it seems like a good general rule of thumb for cis males to avoid antiandrogens of any kind unless they feel like they truly have no other option.

>Up to 38% have experienced sexual side effects.
And it's as low as 0.9%, from your own quote. And I'm pretty sure these numbers include people who get temporary side effects at the start of finasteride use, which disappear the longer they stay on it. Regardless, only ~0.1% have persistent sexual side effects after discontinuing finasteride as the other anon mentioned. The study is selecting people from this 0.1% as part of the finasteride group. It's clear that the depression isn't directly caused by the finasteride itself, it's caused by erectile dysfunction in general, but in this particular study they selected only finasteride-induced ED patients. What's really interesting to me is that 36% of the finasteride group were ok with erectile dysfunction! Anyway, topically applied DHT blockers are still effective at preventing hair loss with virtually no side effects. So do that instead if you're worried. Even if you choose to take it orally, many cis men are willing to take the risk of <0.1% chance of persistent erectile dysfunction (which may not even be permanent in the first place) over 100% chance of baldness. Basically it's 0.1% chance of no pussy or 100% chance of no pussy

>>29064868
>How did you stop repping and what's life like now? I'm always curious to hear stories from people.
thankfully i kinda like blabbing about that part of my life so sure why not

i spent most of my repression dealing with internalized transphobia, self loathing, and feeling conflicted with my religious conservative upbringing.
over time i got more and more jaded until around the final year i started to rapidly masculinize. it got so bad i stopped recognizing myself in the mirror. it was also around that time i found /tttt/ (alongside it's adjacent subreddit 4tr*n).
through these places i saw a very different light to how people feel about and discuss being trans. it really opened me up to a whole other outlook on it. i was also surpised to find out i was FAR from being the only repper.
but what really sealed the deal was being exposed to the concept of boymoding/manmoding. the idea of transitioning medically without transitioning socially really resonated with me. could this be the middle ground for me?
i dwelled on it for a long time. it bottled up until i had a breakdown in the middle of the night. decided right then and there i was going to do something about my dysphoria, and that i was tired of slowly killing myself.

things are a lot better now, the mental changes came first and i'm a lot more clearheaded. i don't mind the lower sex drive one bit. still boymoding at 8 months but i've had a fair share of interesting hijinks with coworkers and family. everybody keeps asking me how i look so young lately lol. i'm still dealing with a lot of internalized feelings and can't really see myself as a woman but i'm doing so much better than when i repressed. i'm taking control over my life for the first time and i'm trying my best.

My point wasn't very clear. Testosterone does increase spermatogenesis. More particularly it is required for maturation of germ cells or gametes into mature sperm. My case is that the processes that make lots of sperm and fast sperm are dependent on the hormonal environment but are independent of the genetic quality of the germ cell. Therefore, someone with low T or low sperm counts doing IVF shouldn't lead to less healthy children.

Not that anon.

A mental illness essentially means that the brain has the inability to use or overuses different parts of itself to such a degree that it can be considered pathological. It becomes a 'broken' brain. Obviously there's people out there who can be considered difficult to handle, like a very aggressive person, but that doesn't inherently mean they have a mental illness. Maybe just a bad upbringing or a low intelligence. Anyway, a mental illness happens *alongside* the person in the brain, it happens alongside the consciousness or the 'you' in the brain. That's why all of these things make a mental illness. The person being subjected to the brain doing unwanted things had no control over them.

If you think about transgenderism as a 'mental' problem, it becomes much easier to deal with it. It's a brain that thinks and expects to be in a certain kind of body, but actually isn't. Instead of dealing with transgenderism as a mental problem we assume the person being dysphoric (I switched to this term now, because then it's more easily seen as a mental illness) is right in their belief of what they are. We don't believe a schizo in their ramblings, so why a dysphoric person? We go so far as to encode that suffering into rules for everyone else to make sure the dysphoric mind isn't upset.

To add on top of that, its very difficult to give the mind what it wants when it comes to physical 'being'. A male mind in a female body wanting a male body is impossible to appease. You've seen the pictures of fleshy appendages that are supposed to represent a penis. If you're female you wouldn't really take that as a replacement for a penis. It's impossible for a male body to become female and vice versa. Sure, you can do HRT or surgery, but it probably won't get close to what the mind wants.

If you would consider transgender dysphoria as a mind issue, and the person in the body is 'suffering' from mental illness, then the issue becomes much easier to deal with.
